thread.title: Melting snow leaves behind magical frozen caves in Scotland
thread.title_full: Melting snow leaves behind magical frozen caves in Scotland - Telegraph

author: Oliver Smith
title: Melting snow leaves behind magical frozen caves in Scotland
text: These striking pictures were captured by Helen Rennie at Ciste Mhearad in the northern Cairngorms. Low summer temperatures mean snow continues to cling to the mountainsides of the Scottish National Park, even in the middle of August. But as the patches begin to melt from below, and water flows downhill, vast caverns – some big enough to walk through – are formed. Snow continues to cling to the mountainsides of the Scottish National Park Photo: Helen Rennie The wavy patterns left behind lend an almost magical quality to the frozen formations. It melts from the bottom up, creating this unusual effect Photo: Helen Rennie It's been a rather dismal summer north of the border, with freezing temperatures recorded in the Highlands in recent weeks. Experts say that more snow has lingered in the Scottish mountains this summer than for at least 20 years. Back in April, Glencoe ski resort received a late dump of around 70cm of fresh snow prompting some to claim that, at the time, it offered the “best powder on the planet” . Skiing in Scotland was still possible in May Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel
